name: Pho
description: A fragrant Vietnamese noodle soup with a savory broth, rice noodles, fresh herbs, and thinly sliced meat.
ingredients: 1 lb thinly sliced raw beef (ribeye or sirloin)
instructions: Rinse the beef bones under cold water. Blanch the bones in boiling water for 5 minutes, then rinse again. This removes impurities.
Char the onion and ginger over an open flame or under a broiler until fragrant and slightly blackened. Scrape off the charred bits and rinse.

In a large stockpot, combine the blanched bones, charred onion and ginger, cinnamon, star anise, cloves, and cardamom. Cover with 12 cups of water and bring to a boil. Reduce to a simmer and cook for at least 2 hours, skimming any foam that rises to the surface.
Strain the broth through a fine-mesh sieve. Discard solids. Season the broth with fish sauce and sugar. Taste and adjust as needed.
Cook the pho noodles according to package directions. Divide the cooked noodles among four large bowls. Arrange the thinly sliced raw beef on top of the noodles.
Ladle the hot, simmering broth over the beef. The heat of the broth will cook the meat. Garnish with fresh herbs, bean sprouts, lime wedges, and jalapenos. Serve immediately.

name: Banh Mi
description: A delicious Vietnamese sandwich on a crisp baguette, filled with savory meats, pickled vegetables, fresh herbs, and a smear of mayonnaise or pate.
ingredients: 1 small baguette or banh mi roll
4-6 slices of Vietnamese ham (cha lua) or roasted pork
instructions: Preheat the oven to 350°F (175°C). Warm the baguette in the oven for 3-5 minutes until warm and crispy.
Slice the baguette lengthwise, but do not cut all the way through. Open it up and spread a layer of pate on one side and mayonnaise on the other.
Layer the meats inside the baguette. Add the sliced cucumber and pickled carrots and daikon.
Tuck in the cilantro sprigs and sliced jalapenos. Finish with a dash of soy sauce.
Serve immediately to enjoy the contrast of the crispy bread and fresh fillings.

name: Goi Cuon
description: Fresh and light Vietnamese spring rolls filled with shrimp, pork, rice vermicelli, and fresh herbs, wrapped in delicate rice paper.
ingredients: 8 large shrimp, peeled, deveined, and cooked
4 oz cooked pork belly or pork loin, thinly sliced
instructions: Prepare all your fillings and set them up on a platter for easy access. Cook and slice the shrimp and pork. Cook the vermicelli noodles and rinse with cold water.
Fill a large shallow dish with warm water. Quickly dip one rice paper wrapper in the water for about 10-15 seconds until it is soft and pliable. Lay it flat on a clean, damp surface.
Place a lettuce leaf in the center of the wrapper. Layer a few pieces of pork, a couple of shrimp, a small handful of vermicelli noodles, and some mint and cilantro on top.
Fold the sides of the rice paper in toward the center. Then, starting from the bottom, tightly roll the wrapper up, like a burrito.
Continue rolling until all wrappers are used. Cut the rolls in half diagonally before serving. Serve with your favorite dipping sauce.

name: Cao Lau
description: A unique noodle dish from Hoi An, Vietnam. It features thick, udon-like noodles, tender pork, fresh herbs, and crispy croutons, with a very small amount of savory broth.
ingredients: 1 lb fresh cao lau noodles (or substitute with udon noodles)
1/2 cup crispy fried croutons or wonton crackers
instructions: In a pot, combine the pork shoulder, soy sauce, sugar, five-spice powder, water, shallots, and garlic. Bring to a simmer, then reduce heat to low, cover, and cook for 1 hour, or until the pork is very tender.
Remove the pork and slice it into thin pieces. Return the pot to the stove and reduce the braising liquid until it becomes a rich, thick sauce.
Cook the cao lau noodles according to package directions. Divide the noodles among four bowls.
Top the noodles with the sliced pork, a small amount of the braising sauce, and a handful of fresh bean sprouts, mint, and cilantro.
Finish each bowl with a generous topping of the crispy croutons or wonton crackers. The dish should have just enough sauce to coat the noodles, not submerge them. Serve immediately.
